ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 111 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 111 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would recommend this course to a student who is interested or thinks they might be interested in field work in environmental studies. Because the class has weekly labs, it gives you a sense of what field work would be like and lets students find out if this is something that they would enjoy pursuing further.
This course was incredibly enjoyable and I learned a lot about scientific writing and lab report writing and I would definitely recommend it to another student.

This is a really really great science credit for someone who doesn't have a wrong background in the sciences. I felt able to keep up and negate with the topics even though I had not taken any sciences for several years. Kealoha is a great professor and you will get to know your classmates very well over the semester. There was more writing than I expected, but lots of support if you ask for it.

As I said above, I really enjoyed the class. As a non-science major, with a limited science background, EVST 234 was a fantastic introduction to field science methods and research. The class is a lot of work, with multiple lab reports due throughout the semester - but you are supported along the way, and you learn a ton. It's so fantastic to spend so much time in the field - from the trip to Yale Myers, to visiting local farms, to utilizing the Peabody's research forest in Guilford - it's an absolutely fantastic introduction to field science methods! It's certainly not a walk in the park, and that's good - there are multiple lab reports, and Kealoha and Max cover a lot of ground throughout the semester. But, if you're looking to learn about forestry, reading the forested landscape, ecological approaches within field science, agricultural field science, urban ecology - you'll come out of the class having learned a ton. And Max and Kealoha are very supportive, and make the class a joy to come to. They're really wonderful people, and are committed to making sure you learn the material, even if it's challenging for you!

This class has two parts: lecture/discussion and lab. Tuesdays are focused around two to three papers, read before, that are then discussed for an hour. Thursdays are a four hour lab period that is almost always spent out in the field collecting specimens or tree samples. The field trips are enjoyable and you learn how to critically read a scientific paper

This is a great opportunity to work outside while learning how to analyze. You learn a lot about sustainable land use practices in a variety of settings, and by the end you know how to hammer out a decent lab report. I would recommend this class, there's certainly a decent amount of work involved, much of which is not fun, but if you have a good class that you can draw support from it's not too hard and you'll have a good time and learn a lot.
This is certainly a class that has a fair amount of work (especially when the labs are due), but overall it's really really fun. You'll learn a lot and get to be outside.
I would absolutely recommend this course, especially if you're itching to get outside more! The lab write ups can be a little stressful, but other than that it was a lot of fun.
